title: The Surprising Truth About What Motivates Us
author: Daniel Pink
review: A compelling breakdown of intrinsic vs extrinsic motivation. The animation format makes complex research accessible.

title: 1,000 True Fans
author: Kevin Kelly
review: The essay that launched a thousand creator economies. Still the clearest articulation of how the internet changes who can make a living from their work.

title: The Gervais Principle
author: Venkatesh Rao
review: Uses The Office as a lens for understanding organizational dynamics. Dense but rewarding.

title: Meditations on Moloch
author: Scott Alexander
review: The definitive essay on coordination failures and why systems optimize for outcomes nobody wants. Changed how I think about incentives.

title: Politics and the English Language
author: George Orwell
review: Orwell's rules for clear writing. Should be required reading for anyone who puts words on a page.

title: What You'll Wish You'd Known
author: Paul Graham
review: Advice to high schoolers that applies to anyone figuring out what to do with their life.

title: This Is Water
author: David Foster Wallace
review: The antidote to default settings. A reminder that awareness is a choice you make every day.

title: The Premium Mediocre Life of Maya Millennial
author: Venkatesh Rao
review: Captures a specific kind of aspirational consumption that feels uncomfortably familiar.

title: How to Do What You Love
author: Paul Graham
review: The essay I return to whenever I'm questioning whether I'm on the right path.

title: The Tyranny of Structurelessness
author: Jo Freeman
review: Written about 70s feminist organizations but applies to any group that thinks it can operate without explicit power structures. Spoiler: you can't.
